elements.content: The CO2 sequestration is extremely urgent due to the growing greenhouse effect and the subsequent serious environmental crisis. The development of porous materials with a size-selective effect for CO2 from other molecules still remains a challenge, due to the difficulties to control pore size within 3–4 Å. Here, we proposed and designed a novel anion-pillared material (termed as ZU-66, ZU = Zhejiang University) embedded with “molecular rotors” toward the industrially relevant CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation. Interestingly, the temporarily fixed molecular rotors under the ambient condition afforded a size-selective channel for CO2 from CH4 and N2. To our best knowledge, there were only a handful of examples achieving the molecular sieving between CO2 and CH4. Such a behavior endowed ZU-66 with high separation selectivity for both CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355) and high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g–1, 298 K, 1 bar). The actual breakthrough experiment further verified its great potential in both CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation. The specific adsorption behavior within ZU-66 was further revealed through the modeling calculation.
elements.clean_text: The CO2 sequestration is extremely urgent due to the growing greenhouse effect and the subsequent serious environmental crisis. The development of porous materials with a size-selective effect for CO2 from other molecules still remains a challenge, due to the difficulties to control pore size within 3-4 Å. Here, we proposed and designed a novel anion-pillared material (termed as ZU-66, ZU = Zhejiang University) embedded with "molecular rotors" toward the industrially relevant CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation. Interestingly, the temporarily fixed molecular rotors under the ambient condition afforded a size-selective channel for CO2 from CH4 and N2. To our best knowledge, there were only a handful of examples achieving the molecular sieving between CO2 and CH4. Such a behavior endowed ZU-66 with high separation selectivity for both CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355) and high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g-1, 298 K, 1 bar). The actual breakthrough experiment further verified its great potential in both CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation. The specific adsorption behavior within ZU-66 was further revealed through the modeling calculation.

elements.content:
A novel anion-pillared material ZU-66 afforded highly selective capture of CO2 from CH4 and N2 mixtures.

Introduction

Carbon dioxide (CO2) sequestration to mitigate massive CO2 emissions derived from energy production and industrial process is imperative to prevent serious consequences on the environment, due to the rapidly increasing atmospheric CO2 concentration (>400 ppm). Natural gas is always mixed with CO2, which not only largely reduces the caloric value of the delivered CH4 but also triggers the danger caused by the corrosion on the transportation pipelines. Additionally, the combustion of carbon-based fossil fuels almost accounts for about 40% of the world’s anthropogenic CO2 emissions, and thus the CO2 capture from the industrial flue gas (termed postcombustion capture, 15% CO2, 85% N2) is also urgent. Therefore, the selective capture of CO2 is of great importance for the reduction of CO2 emissions, also for the purification of natural gas and flue gas. Traditional amine scrubbing ways are limited by high energy consumption to regenerate the sorbent materials accompanied by solvent loss. Relatively, adsorption is recognized as the novel efficient way for CO2 capture, due to its low energy penalty to cover loading and regeneration process.
elements.clean_text:
A novel anion-pillared material ZU-66 afforded highly selective capture of CO2 from CH4 and N2 mixtures.

Introduction

Carbon dioxide (CO2) sequestration to mitigate massive CO2 emissions derived from energy production and industrial process is imperative to prevent serious consequences on the environment, due to the rapidly increasing atmospheric CO2 concentration (>400 ppm). Natural gas is always mixed with CO2, which not only largely reduces the caloric value of the delivered CH4 but also triggers the danger caused by the corrosion on the transportation pipelines. Additionally, the combustion of carbon-based fossil fuels almost accounts for about 40% of the world's anthropogenic CO2 emissions, and thus the CO2 capture from the industrial flue gas (termed postcombustion capture, 15% CO2, 85% N2) is also urgent. Therefore, the selective capture of CO2 is of great importance for the reduction of CO2 emissions, also for the purification of natural gas and flue gas. Traditional amine scrubbing ways are limited by high energy consumption to regenerate the sorbent materials accompanied by solvent loss. Relatively, adsorption is recognized as the novel efficient way for CO2 capture, due to its low energy penalty to cover loading and regeneration process.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a revolutionary class of materials via the self-assembly of metal ions/clusters and organic ligands. And the infinite organic and inorganic chemistries enable us to design the assembled building blocks targeting for the CO2 capture. The common ways such as grafting polar functional groups, or incorporating strong binding sites, are adopted to increase the affinity between the framework and CO2 molecules, but with the lack of satisfactory separation selectivity. On the other hand, molecular sieving as another important separation strategy enables really high separation selectivity. However, the design of materials with molecular sieving in precisely controlled pore-size within 3–4 Å is challenging, especially to those with close molecular dimensions. Therefore, the development of an efficient way to achieve the porous materials with high CO2 separation selectivity and high CO2 capacity is of great importance.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a revolutionary class of materials via the self-assembly of metal ions/clusters and organic ligands. And the infinite organic and inorganic chemistries enable us to design the assembled building blocks targeting for the CO2 capture. The common ways such as grafting polar functional groups, or incorporating strong binding sites, are adopted to increase the affinity between the framework and CO2 molecules, but with the lack of satisfactory separation selectivity. On the other hand, molecular sieving as another important separation strategy enables really high separation selectivity. However, the design of materials with molecular sieving in precisely controlled pore-size within 3-4 Å is challenging, especially to those with close molecular dimensions. Therefore, the development of an efficient way to achieve the porous materials with high CO2 separation selectivity and high CO2 capacity is of great importance.

elements.content: Molecular rotor containing porous materials can be realized by self-assembly of suitable organic or inorganic building blocks. The embedding of ordered rotary groups into the ultramicroporous (<0.7 nm) materials affords the opportunities for fine-tuning the accessible channel size, and it is plausible that the window dynamics of the porous materials can control guest loading into the molecular pores. The series of generated channels with different sizes stemmed from the rotary behavior of molecular rotors, enable us to pick the suitable channel to achieve molecular sieving upon the artificial conditions.
elements.clean_text: Molecular rotor containing porous materials can be realized by self-assembly of suitable organic or inorganic building blocks. The embedding of ordered rotary groups into the ultramicroporous (<0.7 nm) materials affords the opportunities for fine-tuning the accessible channel size, and it is plausible that the window dynamics of the porous materials can control guest loading into the molecular pores. The series of generated channels with different sizes stemmed from the rotary behavior of molecular rotors, enable us to pick the suitable channel to achieve molecular sieving upon the artificial conditions.

elements.content: Anion pillared metal–organic frameworks are a recently emerging platform of porous materials featuring pillared anions. The materials contain two-dimensional square grid assembled with metal nodes and organic ligands, and the anions coordinated to the axial position of metal ions are served as the pillars to form the three-dimensional structure. This kind of ultramicroporous (<0.7 nm) materials have shown great potential in the gas separation, especially for acidic and polar gases, like C2H2/C2H4, C3H4/C3H6, C4H6 purification, SO2 and CO2 capture.
elements.clean_text: Anion pillared metal-organic frameworks are a recently emerging platform of porous materials featuring pillared anions. The materials contain two-dimensional square grid assembled with metal nodes and organic ligands, and the anions coordinated to the axial position of metal ions are served as the pillars to form the three-dimensional structure. This kind of ultramicroporous (<0.7 nm) materials have shown great potential in the gas separation, especially for acidic and polar gases, like C2H2/C2H4, C3H4/C3H6, C4H6 purification, SO2 and CO2 capture.

elements.content: Herein, we envisioned that anion-pillared ultramicroporous materials with embedded molecular rotors would provide opportunities for further fine-tuning of aperture size, enhancing the separation selectivity of CO2 containing mixed gas. A novel anion pillared material ZrFSIX-2-Zn-i (also termed as ZU-66; ZrFSIX = hexafluorozirconium, 2 = 4,4′-bipyridylacetylene, i = interpenetrated) built with molecular rotors was designed, affording a size-selective channel (3.55 Å) for CO2 (3.3 Å) from CH4 (3.8 Å) and N2 (3.65 Å) under the ambient condition. The ZU-66 exhibited exceptionally high CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355) separation selectivity, while retaining the high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g–1). The breakthrough experiment of mixed CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85) further verified its excellent separation performance. The adsorption behavior of CO2 within ZU-66 was revealed by the modeling studies.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we envisioned that anion-pillared ultramicroporous materials with embedded molecular rotors would provide opportunities for further fine-tuning of aperture size, enhancing the separation selectivity of CO2 containing mixed gas. A novel anion pillared material ZrFSIX-2-Zn-i (also termed as ZU-66; ZrFSIX = hexafluorozirconium, 2 = 4,4'-bipyridylacetylene, i = interpenetrated) built with molecular rotors was designed, affording a size-selective channel (3.55 Å) for CO2 (3.3 Å) from CH4 (3.8 Å) and N2 (3.65 Å) under the ambient condition. The ZU-66 exhibited exceptionally high CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355) separation selectivity, while retaining the high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g-1). The breakthrough experiment of mixed CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85) further verified its excellent separation performance. The adsorption behavior of CO2 within ZU-66 was revealed by the modeling studies.

elements.content: Free peripheral aromatic rings with rigid alkyne/alkene centers are suitable for engineering molecular rotors, and 4,4′-bipyridineacetylene here is utilized as the building block. The reaction of 4,4′-bipyridylacetylene and ZnZrF6 afforded the sample of ZU-66. ZU-66 exhibited a prototypal primitive-cubic net with doubly interpenetrated polymorph, giving the maximum square channel of 5.01 Å (, Table S1). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and framework density of the activated ZU-66 were 177 m2 g–1 and 1.54 g cm–3 with aperture size close to 4 Å (Figures S1–S3). The changed structure of ZU-66 after exposure to air could be recovered via the methanol immersion (Figure S4). Thermogravimetric analysis revealed that ZU-66 was stable under 423 K (Figure S5). Differing from the structures of previous Cu metal node based isostructural materials, like SIFSIX-2-Cu-i, GeFSIX-2-Cu-i (also termed as ZU-33), and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, the rotation behavior of pyridines was observed in ZU-66 with Zn metal node, and the pyridines here were served as the “molecular rotors” (A and B). Notably, it was the first time to observe the pyridine rotary behavior in the 4,4′-bipyridineacetylene based anion pillared materials. Because of the Jahn–Teller effect, the coordination geometry of Cu2+ was inclined to the elongated octahedron, and thus the longer Cu–F bond distance (2.28 Å) than Zn–F (2.11 Å) along the c axis (Figure S6A and S6B). The short bond length would enhance the interaction between the anion and the organic linker, therefore the special rotary behavior within ZU-66 (Figure S6C). Here ZrF6 2– was adopted as the pillared anion: the large ionic radius of Zr4+ relative to Si4+, Ti4+, Ge4+ would prompt the delocalization of the charge, affording the more negative F atoms and enhance the interaction between the anion and the pyridine, which may also contribute to the rotation behavior (A,B). The orderly aligned molecular rotors within ZU-66 were able to control the size of accessible channel for the guest molecules, giving the robust framework with dynamics. The channel size was varied from 3.55 to 5.01 Å accompanying with the different degrees of rotary behavior of “molecular rotors” (C). Because such a behavior was affected by external stimuli, it offered us the opportunities to set a suitable aperture for the corresponding guest molecule under the specific given condition. Excitingly, the initial aperture size revealed by the crystal analysis was 3.55 Å, a tailored pore size for the separation of CO2 (3.3 Å) from other molecules, like CH4 and N2 (3.8 and 3.65 Å). If the embedded “molecular rotors” were fixed, ZU-66 was able to afford a perfect molecular sieving for CO2 from CH4 and N2, and offered us a great promise for efficient selective separation of CO2 from CO2/CH4, CO2/N2 mixtures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Free peripheral aromatic rings with rigid alkyne/alkene centers are suitable for engineering molecular rotors, and 4,4'-bipyridineacetylene here is utilized as the building block. The reaction of 4,4'-bipyridylacetylene and ZnZrF6 afforded the sample of ZU-66. ZU-66 exhibited a prototypal primitive-cubic net with doubly interpenetrated polymorph, giving the maximum square channel of 5.01 Å (, Table S1). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and framework density of the activated ZU-66 were 177 m2 g-1 and 1.54 g cm-3 with aperture size close to 4 Å (Figures S1-S3). The changed structure of ZU-66 after exposure to air could be recovered via the methanol immersion (Figure S4). Thermogravimetric analysis revealed that ZU-66 was stable under 423 K (Figure S5). Differing from the structures of previous Cu metal node based isostructural materials, like SIFSIX-2-Cu-i, GeFSIX-2-Cu-i (also termed as ZU-33), and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, the rotation behavior of pyridines was observed in ZU-66 with Zn metal node, and the pyridines here were served as the "molecular rotors" (A and B). Notably, it was the first time to observe the pyridine rotary behavior in the 4,4'-bipyridineacetylene based anion pillared materials. Because of the Jahn-Teller effect, the coordination geometry of Cu2+ was inclined to the elongated octahedron, and thus the longer Cu-F bond distance (2.28 Å) than Zn-F (2.11 Å) along the c axis (Figure S6A and S6B). The short bond length would enhance the interaction between the anion and the organic linker, therefore the special rotary behavior within ZU-66 (Figure S6C). Here ZrF6 2- was adopted as the pillared anion: the large ionic radius of Zr4+ relative to Si4+, Ti4+, Ge4+ would prompt the delocalization of the charge, affording the more negative F atoms and enhance the interaction between the anion and the pyridine, which may also contribute to the rotation behavior (A,B). The orderly aligned molecular rotors within ZU-66 were able to control the size of accessible channel for the guest molecules, giving the robust framework with dynamics. The channel size was varied from 3.55 to 5.01 Å accompanying with the different degrees of rotary behavior of "molecular rotors" (C). Because such a behavior was affected by external stimuli, it offered us the opportunities to set a suitable aperture for the corresponding guest molecule under the specific given condition. Excitingly, the initial aperture size revealed by the crystal analysis was 3.55 Å, a tailored pore size for the separation of CO2 (3.3 Å) from other molecules, like CH4 and N2 (3.8 and 3.65 Å). If the embedded "molecular rotors" were fixed, ZU-66 was able to afford a perfect molecular sieving for CO2 from CH4 and N2, and offered us a great promise for efficient selective separation of CO2 from CO2/CH4, CO2/N2 mixtures.

elements.content: Schematic structure of ZU-66. (A) The structure of ZU-66; the interpenetrated net was highlighted in red. (B) The molecular rotor (4,4′-bipyridylacetylene) embedded in ZU-66. (C) The minimum and maximum channel derived from the rotary behavior of molecular rotors (4,4′-bipyridylacetylene) (color code: F, bright green; Zr, plum; C, gray-40%; H, gray-25%, Zn, sky blue; N, light blue; O, red; the size of channel represents the H–H distance of pyridines after dedcution of the van der Waals of H atoms).
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic structure of ZU-66. (A) The structure of ZU-66; the interpenetrated net was highlighted in red. (B) The molecular rotor (4,4'-bipyridylacetylene) embedded in ZU-66. (C) The minimum and maximum channel derived from the rotary behavior of molecular rotors (4,4'-bipyridylacetylene) (color code: F, bright green; Zr, plum; C, gray-40%; H, gray-25%, Zn, sky blue; N, light blue; O, red; the size of channel represents the H-H distance of pyridines after dedcution of the van der Waals of H atoms).

elements.content: The single component adsorption isotherms for ZU-66 toward CO2, CH4 and N2 varied from 273 K-313 K were collected (A and S7–S9). As shown in A, ZU-66 exhibited really high CO2 capacity, up to 4.56 mmol g–1 (298 K, 1 bar) and negligible CH4 and N2 uptake, only 0.21 mmol g–1 and 0.08 mmol g–1, a near-perfect CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation performance. The CH4 uptake was only half that on GeFSIX-2-Cu-i (0.41 mmol g–1) and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (0.49 mmol g–1), the series of Cu metal node based isostructural materials (B). Because the gas threshold pressure would be delayed with the increasing temperature, it was assumed that molecular rotor within ZU-66 under such conditions was temporarily fixed, acting as a filter for molecules with large size, like CH4 (3.8 Å), N2 (3.65 Å), but allowing the entry of CO2 (3.3 Å) under 298 K and 1 bar. And the stepwise adsorption behavior of CH4 under 273 K on ZU-66 further verified our assumption. The low temperature and high pressure prompted the twist of the molecular rotor, breaking the transitional structure of ZU-66 under ambient condition (Figure S10) and thus the sudden increase of CH4 adsorption, from 0.2 to 0.6 mmol g–1 (C). Further, ZU-66* with collapsed channel was created with only 16 m2 g–1 surface area and almost negligible CO2 uptake (0.4 mmol g–1) (Figures S11 and S12). Consistent with our prediction, the gate opening behavior of CH4 adsorption was not observed on it as well as the materials without “molecular rotors”, like GeFSIX-2-Cu-i and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (C), which further indicated that the sudden increasing CH4 capacity was attributed to the twist of the molecular rotors and the subsequent open channels. The CO2/CH4 uptake ratio of ZU-66 was up to 22, surpassing the most previous reported materials SIFSIX-3-Zn (3.23), HKUST (5.27), ZU-33 (11.2), UTSA-20 (4.85), and was even close to the values of several molecular sieve materials like [Cd2L­(H2O)]2·5H2O (36.4), Qc-5-Cu-sql-β (36), but higher CO2 uptake (4.56 vs 2.05 mmol g–1 [Cd2L­(H2O)]2·5H2O vs 2.16 mmol g–1, Qc-5-Cu-sql-β) (F). The CO2/N2 (57) uptake ratio even exceeded that of [Cd2L­(H2O)]2·5H2O (43.1), only second to that of Qc-5-Cu-sql-β (166), thanks to its high CO2 capacity (F). ZU-66 exhibited both high selectivity and high CO2 capacity, showing great potential for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation.

As shown in A, ZU-66 exhibited really high CO2 capacity, up to 4.56 mmol g-1 (298 K, 1 bar) and negligible CH4 and N2 uptake, only 0.21 mmol g-1 and 0.08 mmol g-1, a near-perfect CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation performance. And the stepwise adsorption behavior of CH4 under 273 K on ZU-66 further verified our assumption. The low temperature and high pressure prompted the twist of the molecular rotor, breaking the transitional structure of ZU-66 under ambient condition (Figure S10) and thus the sudden increase of CH4 adsorption, from 0.2 to 0.6 mmol g-1 (C). The CO2/N2 (57) uptake ratio even exceeded that of [Cd2L(H2O)]2⋅5H2O (43.1), only second to that of Qc-5-Cu-sql-β (166), thanks to its high CO2 capacity (F). ZU-66 exhibited both high selectivity and high CO2 capacity, showing great potential for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation.

elements.content: (A) The adsorption isotherm results of CO2, CH4 and N2 on ZU-66. (B) The CH4 adsorption isotherm results of ZU-66, SIFSIX-2-Cu-i and GeFSIX-2-Cu-i at 298 K. (C) The CH4 adsorption isotherm results of ZU-66, ZU-66*, SIFSIX-2-Cu-i and GeFSIX-2-Cu-i at 273 K. (* ZU-66 with collapsed channel). (D) The calculated CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85) IAST selectivity of ZU-66. (E) The isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption in ZU-66. (F) The comparison of CO2/CH4, CO2/N2 uptake ratio and CO2 uptake of reported materials.
elements.clean_text: 2  (A) The adsorption isotherm results of CO2, CH4 and N2 on ZU-66. (B) The CH4 adsorption isotherm results of ZU-66, SIFSIX-2-Cu-i and GeFSIX-2-Cu-i at 298 K. (C) The CH4 adsorption isotherm results of ZU-66, ZU-66*, SIFSIX-2-Cu-i and GeFSIX-2-Cu-i at 273 K. (* ZU-66 with collapsed channel). (D) The calculated CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85) IAST selectivity of ZU-66. (E) The isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption in ZU-66. (F) The comparison of CO2/CH4, CO2/N2 uptake ratio and CO2 uptake of reported materials.

elements.content: Such a special adsorption behavior endowed ZU-66 with really high separation selectivity for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 under 298 K and 1 bar. The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was utilized to calculate the adsorption selectivity of CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85). The CO2/CH4 selectivity of ZU-66 was up to 136 (1 bar), superior to those of well-known materials with similar CO2 uptake, like HKUST (4), SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (51), Zeolite 13X (103) (D). The selectivity of CO2/N2 was over 350, a very high value among the reported materials (D). The calculated isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 on ZU-66 was only 35 kJ mol–1, a moderate energy value relative to the scrubbing way, indicating the low energy penalty for regeneration (E).
elements.clean_text: Such a special adsorption behavior endowed ZU-66 with really high separation selectivity for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 under 298 K and 1 bar. The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was utilized to calculate the adsorption selectivity of CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85). The CO2/CH4 selectivity of ZU-66 was up to 136 (1 bar), superior to those of well-known materials with similar CO2 uptake, like HKUST (4), SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (51), Zeolite 13X (103) (D). The selectivity of CO2/N2 was over 350, a very high value among the reported materials (D). The calculated isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 on ZU-66 was only 35 kJ mol-1, a moderate energy value relative to the scrubbing way, indicating the low energy penalty for regeneration (E).

elements.content: For the deep understanding about the CO2 adsorption behavior within ZU-66, the simulation via the dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT-D) was performed. As revealed in A, the adsorbed CO2 interacted with only one ZrF6 2– anion, therefore the more available binding sites for CO2, which resulted in its high adsorption capacity and low regeneration energy. Additionally, the adsorbed CO2 molecule was inclined to orient with a torsion angle, about 40.4° to afford the minimum energy conformation (A). The CO2 molecule was bound through the Cδ+···Fδ‑–Zrδ+ electrostatic interactions with the distance of 2.76 Å. The tilted behavior of CO2 molecule afforded the fairly strong multiple van der Waals interactions Oδ‑···Hδ+–Cδ‑ between the CO2 and the framework, and the binding distances were varied from 2.66–2.91 Å (B). The DFT-D calculated binding energy (ΔE) of CO2 molecule on ZU-66 was about 39 kJ mol–1 while that for CH4 was only 24.4 kJ mol–1 (Figure S13). The calculated CO2 binding energy after the introduction of the second CO2 molecule into the cell was almost invariable, about 38.7 kJ mol–1 indicating that the CO2 adsorption within the cell was separated, without interference between each other.
elements.clean_text: For the deep understanding about the CO2 adsorption behavior within ZU-66, the simulation via the dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT-D) was performed. As revealed in A, the adsorbed CO2 interacted with only one ZrF6 2- anion, therefore the more available binding sites for CO2, which resulted in its high adsorption capacity and low regeneration energy. Additionally, the adsorbed CO2 molecule was inclined to orient with a torsion angle, about 40.4° to afford the minimum energy conformation (A). The CO2 molecule was bound through the Cδ+⋅⋅⋅Fδ--Zrδ+ electrostatic interactions with the distance of 2.76 Å. The tilted behavior of CO2 molecule afforded the fairly strong multiple van der Waals interactions Oδ-⋅⋅⋅Hδ+-Cδ- between the CO2 and the framework, and the binding distances were varied from 2.66-2.91 Å (B). The DFT-D calculated binding energy (ΔE) of CO2 molecule on ZU-66 was about 39 kJ mol-1 while that for CH4 was only 24.4 kJ mol-1 (Figure S13). The calculated CO2 binding energy after the introduction of the second CO2 molecule into the cell was almost invariable, about 38.7 kJ mol-1 indicating that the CO2 adsorption within the cell was separated, without interference between each other.

elements.content: Modeling studies of ZU-66 loading with CO2. (A, B) The DFT calculated configuration of ZU-66·CO2 (color code: F, bright green; Zr, plum; C, gray-40%; H, gray-25%; Zn, sky blue; N, light blue; O, red).
elements.clean_text: 3  Modeling studies of ZU-66 loading with CO2. (A, B) The DFT calculated configuration of ZU-66⋅CO2 (color code: F, bright green; Zr, plum; C, gray-40%; H, gray-25%; Zn, sky blue; N, light blue; O, red).

elements.content: To evaluate the actual separation performance of ZU-66 for the CO2 containing mixed gas, both the CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85) mixed gas breakthrough experiments were conducted. As the CO2/CH4 (50/50) mixed gas flowed into the column packed with ZU-66 powder, due to the exclusion effect to CH4, high purified CH4 was immediately eluted, while CO2 was still trapped in the column (A and S14). The CO2 retained time was up to 28 min, and the corresponding CH4 processing capacity was up to 60.1 mL g–1. Additionally, ZU-66 also exhibited highly efficient CO2/N2 separation performance, affording the high N2 processing capacity (132.5 mL g–1), and an efficient adsorbent for the purification of postcombustion gas (Figure S15). The amenability to recycling of ZU-66 was further validated via performing multiple column breakthrough experiments. As shown in the B, almost no obvious decline was observed on both the CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation performance of ZU-66 during the 5 cycles, indicating its good desorption ability and cycle performance. The invariable XRD pattern of the sample after the breakthrough experiment also demonstrated its intact structure (Figure S16). Therefore, ZU-66 is indeed a promising material toward both the separation of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the actual separation performance of ZU-66 for the CO2 containing mixed gas, both the CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85) mixed gas breakthrough experiments were conducted. As the CO2/CH4 (50/50) mixed gas flowed into the column packed with ZU-66 powder, due to the exclusion effect to CH4, high purified CH4 was immediately eluted, while CO2 was still trapped in the column (A and S14). The CO2 retained time was up to 28 min, and the corresponding CH4 processing capacity was up to 60.1 mL g-1. Additionally, ZU-66 also exhibited highly efficient CO2/N2 separation performance, affording the high N2 processing capacity (132.5 mL g-1), and an efficient adsorbent for the purification of postcombustion gas (Figure S15). The amenability to recycling of ZU-66 was further validated via performing multiple column breakthrough experiments. As shown in the B, almost no obvious decline was observed on both the CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation performance of ZU-66 during the 5 cycles, indicating its good desorption ability and cycle performance. The invariable XRD pattern of the sample after the breakthrough experiment also demonstrated its intact structure (Figure S16). Therefore, ZU-66 is indeed a promising material toward both the separation of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2.

elements.content: Breakthrough experiment of ZU-66. (A) The CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 breakthrough performance on ZU-66 under 298 K. (B) The cycling test of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 breakthrough experiment. The desorption condition: 10 mL min–1 of He under 298 K.
elements.clean_text: 4  Breakthrough experiment of ZU-66. (A) The CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 breakthrough performance on ZU-66 under 298 K. (B) The cycling test of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 breakthrough experiment. The desorption condition: 10 mL min-1 of He under 298 K.

elements.content: In summary, a novel anion pillared material ZU-66 embedded with “molecular rotor” was designed through a crystal engineering strategy. It was also the first time to observe the rotation of pyridine rings in the series of 4,4′-bipyridineacetylene based anion pillared materials, stemmed from the adoption of Zn metal node and ZrF6 2– anion. The embedded molecular rotors of pyridine within ZU-66 afforded a size-selective channel for CO2 from CH4 and N2 under the ambient conditions through controlling rotation behavior. Such an interesting behavior endowed ZU-66 with high separation selectivity of CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355), meanwhile the preservation of the high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g–1). The deep insight into the CO2 adsorption behavior within ZU-66 revealed by the DFT calculation demonstrated its moderate binding energy with the framework and thus the low energy penalty for regeneration. The rigid and robust frameworks coexisting with dynamics afford new and interesting properties and offer a new pathway to efficient porous materials design.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a novel anion pillared material ZU-66 embedded with "molecular rotor" was designed through a crystal engineering strategy. It was also the first time to observe the rotation of pyridine rings in the series of 4,4'-bipyridineacetylene based anion pillared materials, stemmed from the adoption of Zn metal node and ZrF6 2- anion. The embedded molecular rotors of pyridine within ZU-66 afforded a size-selective channel for CO2 from CH4 and N2 under the ambient conditions through controlling rotation behavior. Such an interesting behavior endowed ZU-66 with high separation selectivity of CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355), meanwhile the preservation of the high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g-1). The deep insight into the CO2 adsorption behavior within ZU-66 revealed by the DFT calculation demonstrated its moderate binding energy with the framework and thus the low energy penalty for regeneration. The rigid and robust frameworks coexisting with dynamics afford new and interesting properties and offer a new pathway to efficient porous materials design.

elements.content: The ZnZrF6 was synthesized by adding ZnO (2 mol) and ZrO2 (1 mol) into 48%–51% aqueous HF (5 mL) to a Teflon Pouch. The mixture was stirred under room temperature for several minutes and then was heated to 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained ZnZrF6 was filtered and washed with ethanol and dried under 338 K for 3 h.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

Synthesis of ZnZrF6 

Hydrofluoric Acid Is Toxic! The Operation Must Be Carried out under Protective Equipment

The ZnZrF6 was synthesized by adding ZnO (2 mol) and ZrO2 (1 mol) into 48%-51% aqueous HF (5 mL) to a Teflon Pouch. The mixture was stirred under room temperature for several minutes and then was heated to 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained ZnZrF6 was filtered and washed with ethanol and dried under 338 K for 3 h.

elements.content: To a methanol solution (5 mL) of 4,4′-bipyridylacetylene (0.0900 g, 0.5 mmol) was added a methanol solution (5 mL) of ZnZrF6 (0.0675 g, 0.25 mmol). The mixture was heated at 80 °C for 24 h. White powder was obtained by filtration and washed with methanol for several times before using for degas.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of ZrFSIX-2-Zn-i (ZU-66)

To a methanol solution (5 mL) of 4,4'-bipyridylacetylene (0.0900 g, 0.5 mmol) was added a methanol solution (5 mL) of ZnZrF6 (0.0675 g, 0.25 mmol). The mixture was heated at 80 °C for 24 h. White powder was obtained by filtration and washed with methanol for several times before using for degas.

elements.content:
The materials of ZU-33 and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i were synthesized according to previous procedures.

Synthesis of ZU-66*

The activated ZU-66 was first immersed in the water for 1 week. Then the sample was directly filtered and degassed under 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained ZU-66* was characterized by N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K.
elements.clean_text:
The materials of ZU-33 and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i were synthesized according to previous procedures. 

Synthesis of ZU-66*

The activated ZU-66 was first immersed in the water for 1 week. Then the sample was directly filtered and degassed under 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained ZU-66* was characterized by N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K.

elements.content: The CO2, CH4 and N2 adsorption isotherms on various MOFs were performed on the Micromeritics ASAP 2460. Before gas adsorption measurements, the sample of ZU-66, GeFSIX-2-Cu-i and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i were evacuated at 80 °C for 12 h until the vacuum pressure was below 50 μmHg.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Measurements

The CO2, CH4 and N2 adsorption isotherms on various MOFs were performed on the Micromeritics ASAP 2460. Before gas adsorption measurements, the sample of ZU-66, GeFSIX-2-Cu-i and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i were evacuated at 80 °C for 12 h until the vacuum pressure was below 50 μmHg.

elements.content: The adsorption isotherm results of CO2, CH4 and N2 in ZU-66 were fitting with a dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich model. q = q A , sat b A P ν A 1 + b A p ν A + q B , sat b B p ν B 1 + b B p ν B
elements.clean_text:
Fitting of Pure Component Isotherms

The adsorption isotherm results of CO2, CH4 and N2 in ZU-66 were fitting with a dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich model.     q =   q   A , sat       b   A     P     ν   A       1 +   b   A     p     ν   A       +   q   B , sat       b   B     p     ν   B       1 +   b   B     p     ν   B

elements.content: Here, P is the pressure of the bulk gas at equilibrium with the adsorbed phase (kPa), q is the adsorbed amount per mass of adsorbent (mol kg–1), q A,sat and q B,sat are the saturation capacities of site 1 and 2 (mol kg–1), b A and b B are the affinity coefficients of site 1 and 2 (kPa–1), and v A and v B represent the deviations from an ideal homogeneous surface.
elements.clean_text: Here, P is the pressure of the bulk gas at equilibrium with the adsorbed phase (kPa), q is the adsorbed amount per mass of adsorbent (mol kg-1), q A,sat and q B,sat are the saturation capacities of site 1 and 2 (mol kg-1), b A and b B are the affinity coefficients of site 1 and 2 (kPa-1), and v A and v B represent the deviations from an ideal homogeneous surface.

elements.content: The CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 adsorption selectivity is calculated as follows S ads = q 1 / q 2 P 1 / p 2 q 1, and q 2 are the molar loadings in the adsorbed phase in equilibrium with the bulk gas phase with partial pressures p 1 and p 2.
elements.clean_text:
IAST Selectivity Calculation

The CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 adsorption selectivity is calculated as follows        S   ads   =     q   1   /   q   2       P   1   /   p   2         q 1, and q 2 are the molar loadings in the adsorbed phase in equilibrium with the bulk gas phase with partial pressures p 1 and p 2.

elements.content: The static binding energy was calculated using the combination of first-principle density functional theory (DFT) and plane-wave ultrasoft pseudopotential implemented in the Materials Studio, CASTEP code. Calculations were carried out under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange correlation. A cutoff energy of 600 eV and a 2 × 2 × 4 k-point mesh were employed and the total energy convergence was 1 × 10–5 eV atom–1. The structure of ZU-66 and the adsorbed CO2 molecule (the same cell dimensions of ZU-66) were first optimized and relaxed as the reference. The optimized CO2 molecules were then introduced into the channel of ZU-66, followed by a structural optimization (the framework of ZU-66 was treated as a rigid structure). The static binding energy was then calculated: EB = E (MOF) + E (gas) – E (MOF + gas).
elements.clean_text:
Density Functional Theory Calculations

The static binding energy was calculated using the combination of first-principle density functional theory (DFT) and plane-wave ultrasoft pseudopotential implemented in the Materials Studio, CASTEP code. Calculations were carried out under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange correlation. A cutoff energy of 600 eV and a 2 × 2 × 4 k-point mesh were employed and the total energy convergence was 1 × 10-5 eV atom-1. The structure of ZU-66 and the adsorbed CO2 molecule (the same cell dimensions of ZU-66) were first optimized and relaxed as the reference. The optimized CO2 molecules were then introduced into the channel of ZU-66, followed by a structural optimization (the framework of ZU-66 was treated as a rigid structure). The static binding energy was then calculated: EB = E (MOF) + E (gas) - E (MOF + gas).

elements.content: The breakthrough experiments were tested using a dynamic gas breakthrough equipment. The weight packed in the column (4.6 mm inner diameter × 50 mm) was ZU-66 powder (0.43 g), ZU-33 (0.33 g) and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (0.26 g), respectively. The mixed gas of CO2/CH4 = 50/50 (v/v) was introduced at 1.94 mL min–1. The eluted gas was monitored using gas chromatography (GC-490) with the thermal conductivity detector TCD. The mixed gas of CO2/N2 = 15/85 (v/v) was introduced at 2.05 mL min–1. The eluted gas outlet was monitored using gas chromatography (GC-2010 plus) with the thermal conductivity detector TCD. After the breakthrough experiment, the sample was regenerated with He flow 10 mL min–1 under 25 °C for 6 h.
elements.clean_text:
Breakthrough Experiments

The breakthrough experiments were tested using a dynamic gas breakthrough equipment. The weight packed in the column (4.6 mm inner diameter × 50 mm) was ZU-66 powder (0.43 g), ZU-33 (0.33 g) and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (0.26 g), respectively. The mixed gas of CO2/CH4 = 50/50 (v/v) was introduced at 1.94 mL min-1. The eluted gas was monitored using gas chromatography (GC-490) with the thermal conductivity detector TCD. The mixed gas of CO2/N2 = 15/85 (v/v) was introduced at 2.05 mL min-1. The eluted gas outlet was monitored using gas chromatography (GC-2010 plus) with the thermal conductivity detector TCD. After the breakthrough experiment, the sample was regenerated with He flow 10 mL min-1 under 25 °C for 6 h.

cln_elements.content:
The CO2 sequestration is extremely urgent due to the growing greenhouse effect and the subsequent serious environmental crisis. The development of porous materials with a size-selective effect for CO2 from other molecules still remains a challenge, due to the difficulties to control pore size within 3–4 Å. Here, we proposed and designed a novel anion-pillared material (termed as ZU-66, ZU = Zhejiang University) embedded with “molecular rotors” toward the industrially relevant CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation. Interestingly, the temporarily fixed molecular rotors under the ambient condition afforded a size-selective channel for CO2 from CH4 and N2. To our best knowledge, there were only a handful of examples achieving the molecular sieving between CO2 and CH4. Such a behavior endowed ZU-66 with high separation selectivity for both CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355) and high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g–1, 298 K, 1 bar). The actual breakthrough experiment further verified its great potential in both CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation. The specific adsorption behavior within ZU-66 was further revealed through the modeling calculation.

Herein, we envisioned that anion-pillared ultramicroporous materials with embedded molecular rotors would provide opportunities for further fine-tuning of aperture size, enhancing the separation selectivity of CO2 containing mixed gas. A novel anion pillared material ZrFSIX-2-Zn-i (also termed as ZU-66; ZrFSIX = hexafluorozirconium, 2 = 4,4′-bipyridylacetylene, i = interpenetrated) built with molecular rotors was designed, affording a size-selective channel (3.55 Å) for CO2 (3.3 Å) from CH4 (3.8 Å) and N2 (3.65 Å) under the ambient condition. The ZU-66 exhibited exceptionally high CO2/CH4 (136) and CO2/N2 (355) separation selectivity, while retaining the high CO2 capacity (4.56 mmol g–1). The breakthrough experiment of mixed CO2/CH4 (50/50) and CO2/N2 (15/85) further verified its excellent separation performance. The adsorption behavior of CO2 within ZU-66 was revealed by the modeling studies.

Results and Discussion

Free peripheral aromatic rings with rigid alkyne/alkene centers are suitable for engineering molecular rotors, and 4,4′-bipyridineacetylene here is utilized as the building block. The reaction of 4,4′-bipyridylacetylene and ZnZrF6 afforded the sample of ZU-66. ZU-66 exhibited a prototypal primitive-cubic net with doubly interpenetrated polymorph, giving the maximum square channel of 5.01 Å (, Table S1). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and framework density of the activated ZU-66 were 177 m2 g–1 and 1.54 g cm–3 with aperture size close to 4 Å (Figures S1–S3). The changed structure of ZU-66 after exposure to air could be recovered via the methanol immersion (Figure S4). Thermogravimetric analysis revealed that ZU-66 was stable under 423 K (Figure S5). Differing from the structures of previous Cu metal node based isostructural materials, like SIFSIX-2-Cu-i, GeFSIX-2-Cu-i (also termed as ZU-33), and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, the rotation behavior of pyridines was observed in ZU-66 with Zn metal node, and the pyridines here were served as the “molecular rotors” (A and B). Notably, it was the first time to observe the pyridine rotary behavior in the 4,4′-bipyridineacetylene based anion pillared materials. Because of the Jahn–Teller effect, the coordination geometry of Cu2+ was inclined to the elongated octahedron, and thus the longer Cu–F bond distance (2.28 Å) than Zn–F (2.11 Å) along the c axis (Figure S6A and S6B). The short bond length would enhance the interaction between the anion and the organic linker, therefore the special rotary behavior within ZU-66 (Figure S6C). Here ZrF6 2– was adopted as the pillared anion: the large ionic radius of Zr4+ relative to Si4+, Ti4+, Ge4+ would prompt the delocalization of the charge, affording the more negative F atoms and enhance the interaction between the anion and the pyridine, which may also contribute to the rotation behavior (A,B). The orderly aligned molecular rotors within ZU-66 were able to control the size of accessible channel for the guest molecules, giving the robust framework with dynamics. The channel size was varied from 3.55 to 5.01 Å accompanying with the different degrees of rotary behavior of “molecular rotors” (C). Because such a behavior was affected by external stimuli, it offered us the opportunities to set a suitable aperture for the corresponding guest molecule under the specific given condition. Excitingly, the initial aperture size revealed by the crystal analysis was 3.55 Å, a tailored pore size for the separation of CO2 (3.3 Å) from other molecules, like CH4 and N2 (3.8 and 3.65 Å). If the embedded “molecular rotors” were fixed, ZU-66 was able to afford a perfect molecular sieving for CO2 from CH4 and N2, and offered us a great promise for efficient selective separation of CO2 from CO2/CH4, CO2/N2 mixtures.

The single component adsorption isotherms for ZU-66 toward CO2, CH4 and N2 varied from 273 K-313 K were collected (A and S7–S9). As shown in A, ZU-66 exhibited really high CO2 capacity, up to 4.56 mmol g–1 (298 K, 1 bar) and negligible CH4 and N2 uptake, only 0.21 mmol g–1 and 0.08 mmol g–1, a near-perfect CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation performance. The CH4 uptake was only half that on GeFSIX-2-Cu-i (0.41 mmol g–1) and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (0.49 mmol g–1), the series of Cu metal node based isostructural materials (B). Because the gas threshold pressure would be delayed with the increasing temperature, it was assumed that molecular rotor within ZU-66 under such conditions was temporarily fixed, acting as a filter for molecules with large size, like CH4 (3.8 Å), N2 (3.65 Å), but allowing the entry of CO2 (3.3 Å) under 298 K and 1 bar. And the stepwise adsorption behavior of CH4 under 273 K on ZU-66 further verified our assumption. The low temperature and high pressure prompted the twist of the molecular rotor, breaking the transitional structure of ZU-66 under ambient condition (Figure S10) and thus the sudden increase of CH4 adsorption, from 0.2 to 0.6 mmol g–1 (C). Further, ZU-66* with collapsed channel was created with only 16 m2 g–1 surface area and almost negligible CO2 uptake (0.4 mmol g–1) (Figures S11 and S12). Consistent with our prediction, the gate opening behavior of CH4 adsorption was not observed on it as well as the materials without “molecular rotors”, like GeFSIX-2-Cu-i and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (C), which further indicated that the sudden increasing CH4 capacity was attributed to the twist of the molecular rotors and the subsequent open channels. The CO2/CH4 uptake ratio of ZU-66 was up to 22, surpassing the most previous reported materials SIFSIX-3-Zn (3.23), HKUST (5.27), ZU-33 (11.2), UTSA-20 (4.85), and was even close to the values of several molecular sieve materials like [Cd2L­(H2O)]2·5H2O (36.4), Qc-5-Cu-sql-β (36), but higher CO2 uptake (4.56 vs 2.05 mmol g–1 [Cd2L­(H2O)]2·5H2O vs 2.16 mmol g–1, Qc-5-Cu-sql-β) (F). The CO2/N2 (57) uptake ratio even exceeded that of [Cd2L­(H2O)]2·5H2O (43.1), only second to that of Qc-5-Cu-sql-β (166), thanks to its high CO2 capacity (F). ZU-66 exhibited both high selectivity and high CO2 capacity, showing great potential for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation.

Further, ZU-66* with collapsed channel was created with only 16 m2 g-1 surface area and almost negligible CO2 uptake (0.4 mmol g-1) (Figures S11 and S12). Consistent with our prediction, the gate opening behavior of CH4 adsorption was not observed on it as well as the materials without "molecular rotors", like GeFSIX-2-Cu-i and SIFSIX-2-Cu-i (C), which further indicated that the sudden increasing CH4 capacity was attributed to the twist of the molecular rotors and the subsequent open channels. The CO2/CH4 uptake ratio of ZU-66 was up to 22, surpassing the most previous reported materials SIFSIX-3-Zn (3.23), HKUST (5.27), ZU-33 (11.2), UTSA-20 (4.85), and was even close to the values of several molecular sieve materials like [Cd2L(H2O)]2⋅5H2O (36.4), Qc-5-Cu-sql-β (36), but higher CO2 uptake (4.56 vs 2.05 mmol g-1 [Cd2L(H2O)]2⋅5H2O vs 2.16 mmol g-1, Qc-5-Cu-sql-β) (F). The CO2/N2 (57) uptake ratio even exceeded that of [Cd2L(H2O)]2⋅5H2O (43.1), only second to that of Qc-5-Cu-sql-β (166), thanks to its high CO2 capacity (F). ZU-66 exhibited both high selectivity and high CO2 capacity, showing great potential for CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 separation.

metadata.title:
Anion Pillared Metal–Organic Framework Embedded
with Molecular Rotors for Size-Selective Capture of CO2 from CH4 and N2
